indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Indicators: 1a. Number of MHP projects implemented 1b. Number of households with access to an improved sustainable energy supply 1c. Number of regional energy awarness training conducted 2a. Number of transport sector projects implemented 2b. Number of households with access to improved transport infrastructure 3a. Number of public buildings and facility projects implemented 3b. Number of households with improved access to public buildings/facilities 4a. Number of disaster mitigation projects implemented 4b. Number of households benefiting from disaster mitigation projects 5a. Number of irrigation projects implemented 5b. Number of households benefiting from irrigation and agricultural projects 6a. Number of water supply projects implemented 6b. Number of households with access to potable water 7. Number of labour days created 8a. % progress on dam project in Badghis 8b.% progress in dam construction work 9a. % progress on water supply project main transmission line in Badghis 9b.% progress on City Water supply Network 10. Ongoing support to key Government entities in Badghis maintained i.e Machinery Park, MOWA, Water Testing Unit and Municipality

baseline.comment: Baseline: 1a. 174 MHP projects implemented generating 3.06 MW electricity. 1b. 34,329 Households with access to improved sustainable energy supply 1c. not data 2a. 519 transport sector projects implemented 2b. 641158 households with access to improved transport infrastructure 3a. 146 public buildings and facility projects implemented 3b. 344827 households with improved access to public buildings/facilities 4a. 795 disaster mitigation projects implemented 4b. 850409 households benefiting from disaster mitigation projects 5a. 428 irrigation projects implemented 5b. 536594 households benefiting from irrigation projects 6a. 595 water supply project implemented 6b. 312205 households with access to potable water 7. 2829458 labour days created 8a. 50% feasibility study and design completed 8.b. no data 9a. 51 %Water supply main transmission struction completed 9b. City water supply Network surveyed 10. Handover activities from AECID done

target.comment:
2015 Annual Targets:
1a. 15 ongoing Micro Hydro Power and 1 pilot bio-gas will be completed, generating 652 KW of electricity 1b.3632 household with access to sustainable energy supply through electricity generated with MHP 1c.1462 Provincial Rural Rehabilitation and Development (PRRD) staff and District Development Assembly members will receive renewable energy awareness training 2a. 16 transport sector project implemented 2b. 57127 households will access improved transport infrastructure 3a 9 Public building implemented 3b. 25633 household will access to improved public building/facilities 4a 21 disaster mitigation projects implemented 4b. 47613 households benefiting from disaster mitigation projects 5a.13 irrigation project will be implemented 5b. 3575 households will be benefited from implementation of improved irrigation projects 6a.13 water supply project will be implemented 6b. 4,822 households will have access to potable water 7a. approximately 1,144367 labor days will be created through implementation of NABDP project in year 2015. 8a. 100% Feasibility Study and design will be completed 8b. no data 9a. 100% water supply main transmission line structure completed 9b. 40% city water supply network completed 10. AECID activities will smoothly be progressed

actual.comment: 1.a. 5 1.b. 4,450 HH 1.c. 0 2.a. 0 2.b. 0 3.a. 2 3.b. 3,755 4.a. 7 4.b. 12,538 5.a. 5 5.b. 4,530 6.a. 1 6.b. 180 7.a. 77,587 labour days 8.a. 0 9.a. 9.b. 60% progress on water supply project 10.a. All the related activities are going smoothly

location.name: Afghanistan
location.activity-description: This output supports all Provincial Governor Offices and Provincial Councils throughout Afghanistan.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: (1) # of provinces having CD plan and strategies (2) # of Provincial Strategic Plans (PSPs) prepared (3) # of Provincial Development Plans (PDPs) prepared with ASGP support through a structured and participatory process (4) # of provinces with Citizen Service Centers for improved access to information and responsive governance (5) # of PGOs and DGOs with functioning admin. management system in accordance with IDLG operating guidelines (6) # of PCs trained in exercising oversight and representative functions in compliance with PC law

baseline.comment: 2.1. 81% in the PGOs and 72% in the DGOs 2.2. 3% in the PGOs and 0% in the DGOs 2.3. 59% in the PGOs and 46% in the DGOs 2.4. 8 PGOs and 3 DGOs 2.5. GOFORGOLD performance measurement system developed but not utilized at all due to its abstract and resourece-demanding nature 2.6. 4 PGOs 2.7. PSPs prepared in 7 provinces. PDPs prepared in all the provinces 2.8. None of the PGOs have liquidated LOA advances on time (affected by delays in Kabul) 2.9. GDCLCA does not have its page on the IDLG website 2.10. 27 2.11. 24

target.comment: 2.1 Number of tashkeel positions filled in PGOs and targeted DGOs. 95% of tashkeel positions filled in the Provincial Governors Office (PGOs). Female tashkeel constitute 3% of all employed tashkeel in the PGO. Female tashkeel constitute 5% of all employed tashkeel in the PGO 15 PGOs and 15 District Governors (DGOs) implement promotional/motivational activities to advocate for female recruitment. 2.2: 14 PGO HR plans includes Gender Mainstreaming (GM) session. 2.3: 50% of PGO and 25% 0f targeted DGO tashkeel staff trained on Office Manual. 2.4: Ten PGOs and five DGOs with a separate female toilet facility. 2.5: 23 PGOs have Provincial Gender Committees to support gender sensitive service delivery. 2.6:10 PGOs Implement Communication Strategies. 2.7: 34 Provinces Have Completed Provincial Development Plan (PDPs) and 10 Have Current and Completed Provincial Strategic Plans (PSPs). 2.8: 13 PGOs hold PDP conferences/ workshops/initiatives to launch/ develop the PDP. 2.9: 10 PGOs include tashkeel staff who receive Public Financial Management training during 2014. 2.10: All Provincial Council (PCs) hold twice monthly meetings with the PGO and also hold monthly internal meetings. 2.11: 306 PC members and 46 tashkeel staff receive training and orientation on PC law and responsibilities, relationship with line departments 2.12: 17 PCs (50%) include members that undertake monitoring missions to districts

actual.comment: 2.1. 95% of tashkeel positions filled in the PGOs, Female tashkeel constitute 4% of all PGO employed tashkeel. 9 PGOs implement promotional/motivational activities to advocate for female recruitment. 2.2. 8 PGO HR plans includes GM session. 2.3. 30% of PGO personnel have received training on Office Manual 2.4. Fifteen PGOs - On target. Cumulative target. 2.5. Off target, due to PGOs focus on other interests. Mitigating measures include support to other gender initiatives and gender policy, as outlined in the report. 2.6. On target. Cumulative target. 22 PGOs Have Communication Strategies: 2.7. On Target. Provinces Have Completed PDPs and PSPs: 34 Provinces Have Completed PDPs and five Have Completed PSPs. 2.8. On target. Number of PGOs that hold PDP conferences/ workshops/initiatives to launch/ develop the PDP: 23 PGOs. 2.9. On Target. PGOs with tashkeel staff who receive Public Financial Management training in line with MOF policy. 2.10. On Target. 34 PCs hold 102 IMs. 34 PCs hold 198 internal meetings (IMs) following the rules and procedures. 2.11. On Target. 120 PC members receive CD training during the quarter, and 240 total during 2015. 2.12. 17 PCs undertake 102 monitoring mission to 34 districts.

result.title: Objective
result.description: Strengthening the resilience of rural livelihood options for Afghan communities in Panjshir, Balkh, Uruzgan and Herat Provinces to manage climate change-induced disaster risks

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
1.Capacity of MAIL as per capacity assessment scorecard (baseline: 3; target: 4 )
2. Domestic finance committed to the relevant institutions to integrate climate change information in development planning

baseline.comment:
3
Minimal

target.comment:
To achieve the Capacity Scorecard score of 4
Domestic target financing is $10 million per year

actual.comment: A ban on Government recruitments was imposed soon after the change of presidency in the country on 31 September 2014 until the nomination and appointment of the new Minister, in May, 2015. Because of this, the MAIL could only hire project manager and senior irrigation engineer but not the full relevant technical team, according to schedule. Hence, the results expected during the first year of implementation were not met.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Climate change risk and variability integrated into local planning and budgeting processes

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Amount of budget allocated specifically for climate change adaptation measures in development plans at the provincial level and community development plans (CDCs)
Extent to which climate change information and adaptation measures are incorporated into MAIL local development plans in 4 provinces
Number of climate change scenarios developed for the agriculture sector in selected provinces
Number of MAIL officials, farmers, and pastoralists trained on climate risk information and appropriate response measures

baseline.comment:
Capacity for climate-related analysis and forward planning is limited at national and sub-national level.
Institutional capacity for cross-sectoral climate change planning is negligible
0
0

target.comment:
By end of project, 15 communities and 4 provincial task teams have been trained in and use climate related vulnerability and risk assessments in an integrated area-based planning approach.
Climate resilient investment strategies based on integrated climate resilient development plans are in place and attracting funding.
4 climate change scenarios developed
At least 250 MAIL officials, farmers, and pastoralists trained

actual.comment:
So far, 0 communities and 0 provincial task teams have been trained in and use climate related vulnerability and risk assessments in an integrated area-based planning approach.
So far, 0 climate resilient investment strategies based on integrated climate resilient development plans are in place and attracting funding.
0 climate change scenarios developed.
So far, 0 MAIL officials, farmers, and pastoralists trained.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Rural income and livelihood opportunities for vulnerable communities enhanced and diversified

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Percentage of project beneficiaries surveyed reporting to gain an increase in personal monthly income at least by 30%
Percentage of beneficiaries households that engage in more than two climate proof livelihoods opportunities
Number of women trained on alternative livelihoods to farming
Number of rural entrepreneurs and SMEs trained in business development for handicrafts and small-scale manufacturing
Number of hectares of degraded rangelands planted with stress resistant seedling varieties

baseline.comment:
Women and Farmers currently constrained by limited access to and knowledge of diversified livelihood opportunities.
Currently there is a lack of access to training, markets, raw materials and financing.
0
0
0

target.comment:
By the end of the project, 800 women and over 30 SMEs have been trained in and tested alternative livelihoods options, of which 35% have adopted them permanently.
By the end of the project local administration task teams are able to deliver livelihood diversification support to women and SMEs
At least 800 women trained
50 rural entrepreneurs and 30 SMEs trained in business development
2,000 hectares of degraded rangelands rehabilitated

actual.comment:
So far, 0 beneficiaries have been surveyed.
So far, 0 beneficiaries have been engaged in more than 2 climate-proof livelihoods opportunities.
0 women trained on alternative livelihoods to farming.
So far, 0 rural entrepreneurs and SMEs trained in business development for handicrafts and small-scale manufacturing.
0 hectares of degraded rangelands planted with stress resistant seedling varieties.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Crop productivity level from irrigated agriculture (X tons of crops per hectare)
Amount of crops and livelihoods assets damaged by floods or drought in the targeted areas
Number of small-scale storage reservoirs built in selected river sub-basins
Number of communities where micro-water harvesting techniques are introduced
Number of karezes and canals improved and rehabilitated to reduce water losses
Number of check dams, contour bunds and other facilities built to conserve water and enhance groundwater recharge

baseline.comment:
Very limited capacity for applying climate resilient agriculture
Informal coping strategies are in use in target areas, no formal infrastructure risk reducing/insurance approaches yet in place due to lack of knowledge and hazard information in target areas
0
0
0
0

target.comment:
By the end of the project, climate resilient agricultural production has increased by 10% in target areas compared to baseline (1t/ha maize) adjusted for rainfall.
By the end of the project at least 25% agricultural infrastructure in the target communities is improved to insure against the inherent uncertainty of climate change
12 small-scale storage reservoirs built
Micro-water harvesting techniques introduced in 12 communities
20 karezes and canals improved and rehabilitated
At least 20 check dams, contour bunds, and other facilities built

actual.comment:
0 tons of crops per hectare from irrigated agriculture.
0 number of agricultural infrastructure improved yet in target communities.
0 number of small-scale storage reservoirs built.
0 number of small-scale storage reservoirs built in selected river sub-basins.
0 number of communities where micro-water harvesting techniques are introduced.
0 number of karezes and canals improved and rehabilitated to reduce water losses.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: A. Percentage change in progress of MOIA maturity ratings (conducted annually and not applicable in this phase) B. Extent to which Change Management, Capacity Development, Aid Coordination units and M&E systems are established and functional C. Percentage of women personnel in Aid Coordination unit

baseline.comment: A. Institutional maturity ratings for Office of DM Policy and Strategy from 2015 LOTFA VII Institutional Assessment in place (estimated from 2014) B. Approval for M&E systems in place (2014) C. 0 percent (2014)

target.comment: A. Not applicable during this phase. B. Policy developed and approved for Change Management, Capacity Development and Aid Coordination, with ToR developed and staff assigned; M&E Procedures and Tools templates developed. Training initiated for M&E staff. C. 25 percent

actual.comment: A. Unified M&E framework adopted and reporting format developed to facilitate result outcomes for all its departments B. MOIA engaged in discussions regarding the establishment, governance and structure of the Change Management and Capacity Development units. Concept notes and TORs also developed. M&E Standard Operating Procedures and formats were completed and select staff trained in their use. Capacity developed for select staff of the Office of the Deputy Minister for Policy and Strategy and focal points in seven pilot departments C. Coordination underway with new General Directorate for International Cooperation. Database expert is on board and providing technical services related to information technology needs.

target.comment:
TARGETS (Phase 2: Jan-Jun 2016) A: 0.5 point overall increase per Phase 1 target B: Partially functional. Procedures and Tools developed for Change Management, Capacity Development and Aid Coordination units; Training completed for M&E staff and initiated for Change Management, Capacity Development and Aid Coordination staff; M&E plans developed and piloted C: Not less than 25 per cent of transferred-in uniformed staff and new civilian recruits are female
TARGETS (Phase 3: Jul-Dec 2016) A: 0.5 point overall increase (per Phase 2 Target B.Wholly functional in the centre; at least partially functional at subnational level where required. Training completed for Change Management, Capacity Development and Aid Coordination staff; M&E plans developed and implemented according to the procedures for the MOIA; Change Management and Capacity Development plans developed and piloted; Aid Coordination unit actively leads on aid coordination issues (including functions previously undertaken by IPCB). C. As phase 2

baseline.comment: A. 4 (in June 2015) B. No Action plan (in 2015) C. 31 in 3 provinces (in June 2015) D. 4 (in 2015) E. No action plan (in June 2015) F. 1 District Safety Security Survey conducted covering 8 provinces (in June 2015)

target.comment: A. 8 B. Action plan prepared and agreed for Police-womens Councils. C. 0 for this Phase D. 6 E. Action plan developed. F. 2 District Safety Security Survey conducted covering 12 provinces

actual.comment: A. COP Foundation Training provided to ANP/PeM in Kabul, Herat, and Mazar and to be rolled out to new PeM units in 12 provinces B. The second national Conference on Police Women Council (PWC) was successfully convened and an action plan of priorities was developed to make PWC effective and better able to contribute to police professionalization C. Consultation with MOIA conducted for the establishment of 40 new Information Desks. Terms of Reference for the establishment and training of 390 Information Desk Police Officers developed and at the review stage D. 119 service in Kandahar has been reactivated. MOIA requested also the reactivation of Helmand. Capacity development is yet to be started. Two provinces for 119 service expansion to be agreed by MOIA. E. Requirements identified and list of additional districts and provinces for expansion agreed by MOIA F. DSSS completed and specific recommendations to be used in identifying police priorities by the respective districts and the MOIA in general

iati-activity.title: Sustainable Development Goals
iati-activity.description: Enabling The Ministry of Economy to lead on coordinating and monitoring the SDGS on behalf of the Government of Afghanistan.

iati-activity.description: MoEC requires technical assistance to fulfill its mandate to lead the national coordination and monitoring of the SDGs and to align the national planning and budgeting process with the SDGs.
